title: Vaccines, Live, Viral: Drug Class, Uses, Side Effects, Drug Names
author: Medical Reviewer Sarfaroj Khan; BHMS; PGD Health Operations
description: Live viral vaccines are biological products that provide immunity against certain viral infections. Learn about how they work, usages, side effects, and a list of drugs.
cleaned_text: How do live viral vaccines work? Live [viral](https://www.rxlist.com/viral/definition.htm) [vaccines](https://www.rxlist.com/vaccines/definition.htm) are biological products that provide [immunity](https://www.rxlist.com/immunity/definition.htm) against certain viral infections. Live viral vaccines stimulate the body's [immune system](https://www.rxlist.com/immune_system/definition.htm) to produce antibodies against specific types of [viruses](https://www.rxlist.com/viruses/definition.htm) and protect a person from diseases caused by these viruses. Live viral vaccines are weakened ( [attenuated](https://www.rxlist.com/attenuated/definition.htm)) forms of [disease](https://www.rxlist.com/disease/definition.htm)-causing viruses. Live viral vaccines produce a strong and often life-long immunity similar to that [acquired](https://www.rxlist.com/acquired/definition.htm) from a natural [infection](https://www.rxlist.com/infection/definition.htm), but without subjecting the person to the disease and its complications, because they only contain a small amount of the weakened viruses. Live viral vaccines are derived by weakening the disease-causing viruses [in](https://www.rxlist.com/in/definition.htm) laboratories, usually with repeated culturing. Live viral vaccines must be stored and handled with care because they are fragile and can be damaged by heat and light. Live viral vaccines may not be safe for individuals with compromised immunity. People with weakened [immune](https://www.rxlist.com/immune/definition.htm) systems should consult with their [health](https://www.rxlist.com/health/definition.htm) care providers before receiving live viral vaccines, because they may cause severe infections that their weakened immune systems may not be able to [control](https://www.rxlist.com/control_research/definition.htm). Live viral vaccines approved by the [FDA](https://www.rxlist.com/fda/definition.htm) provide immunity against the following viral diseases: [Febrile](https://www.rxlist.com/febrile/definition.htm) [acute respiratory disease](https://www.rxlist.com/acute_respiratory_disease/definition.htm), caused by [adenovirus](https://www.rxlist.com/adenovirus-drug.htm)type 7 [Dengue](https://www.rxlist.com/dengue/definition.htm)disease, caused by dengue [virus](https://www.rxlist.com/virus/definition.htm)serotypes 1,2,3 and 4, spread by mosquitoes - infection [Influenza A](https://www.rxlist.com/consumer_audenz/drugs-condition.htm)and B infection [Measles](https://www.rxlist.com/measles/definition.htm), [mumps](https://www.rxlist.com/mumps/definition.htm), [Chickenpox](https://www.rxlist.com/chickenpox/definition.htm), caused by the [varicella](https://www.rxlist.com/varicella_chickenpox/definition.htm)-zoster virus [Gastroenteritis](https://www.rxlist.com/gastroenteritis/definition.htm)caused by several strains of [rotavirus](https://www.rxlist.com/rotavirus/definition.htm) [Smallpox](https://www.rxlist.com/smallpox/definition.htm), which has been eradicated worldwide [Monkeypox](https://www.rxlist.com/monkeypox/definition.htm), a disease caused by the monkeypox virus which is related to the smallpox virus [Yellow fever](https://www.rxlist.com/yellow_fever/definition.htm), a disease spread by mosquitoes, affects the [liver](https://www.rxlist.com/liver/definition.htm) How are live viral vaccines used? Live viral vaccines are administered as single or a series of one-time doses, except in the case of the [influenza virus vaccine](https://www.rxlist.com/consumer_flublok/drugs-condition.htm) which is administered annually before the [flu](https://www.rxlist.com/flu/definition.htm) season. Live viral vaccines may be administered through the following routes: [Oral](https://www.rxlist.com/oral/definition.htm)tablets, solutions, or suspensions - Intranasal sprays [Subcutaneous](https://www.rxlist.com/subcutaneous/definition.htm)(SC) injections into the [tissue](https://www.rxlist.com/tissue/definition.htm)under the [skin](https://www.rxlist.com/skin/definition.htm) [Percutaneous](https://www.rxlist.com/percutaneous/definition.htm)administration into the skin [Intramuscular](https://www.rxlist.com/intramuscular_im/definition.htm)(IM) injections into the [muscle](https://www.rxlist.com/muscle/definition.htm) Live viral vaccines approved by the FDA include: - Adenovirus type 4 and type 7 vaccine for individuals of ages 17-50 years - Dengue virus vaccine for children of ages 9-16 years with [laboratory](https://www.rxlist.com/laboratory/definition.htm)-confirmed previous dengue infection and living in [endemic](https://www.rxlist.com/endemic/definition.htm)areas - Ebola Zaire vaccine for adults [Influenza](https://www.rxlist.com/influenza/definition.htm)intranasal vaccine for individuals of ages 2-49 - Measles, mumps, and [rubella vaccine](https://www.rxlist.com/rubella_vaccine/definition.htm)for routine [immunization](https://www.rxlist.com/immunization/definition.htm)in children and adults, and immunization for [pregnant](https://www.rxlist.com/pregnant/definition.htm)women without evidence of immunity, after termination or completion of [pregnancy](https://www.rxlist.com/pregnancy/definition.htm) - Measles, mumps, rubella, and varicella vaccine for children of ages 12 months to 12 years - Rotavirus oral vaccine for [prophylaxis](https://www.rxlist.com/prophylaxis/definition.htm)in infants of ages 6-32 weeks [Smallpox vaccine](https://www.rxlist.com/smallpox_vaccine/definition.htm), now no longer routinely administered since smallpox has been eradicated in the world - Smallpox and monkeypox vaccine for adults who are at high risk for smallpox or monkeypox infection - Varicella virus vaccine for individuals of age 12 months and older [Yellow fever vaccine](https://www.rxlist.com/consumer_yellow_fever_vaccine_yf_vax/drugs-condition.htm)for individuals 9 months and older who live in or travel to yellow [fever](https://www.rxlist.com/fever/definition.htm)endemic areas, and laboratory personnel at risk for exposure What are side effects of live viral vaccines? Side effects of live viral vaccines may include the following: - Injection site reactions Varicella infection Skin infections such as [cellulitis](https://www.rxlist.com/cellulitis/definition.htm)and [impetigo](https://www.rxlist.com/impetigo/definition.htm) - [Parotitis](https://www.rxlist.com/parotitis/definition.htm)(inflammation of the parotid glands) [Orchitis](https://www.rxlist.com/orchitis/definition.htm)(testicle inflammation) [Epididymitis](https://www.rxlist.com/epididymitis/definition.htm)(inflammation of the coiled [tube](https://www.rxlist.com/tube/definition.htm)in the testicle that of the [eye](https://www.rxlist.com/eye/definition.htm)and inner surface of eyelids) [Eyelid](https://www.rxlist.com/eyelid/definition.htm) [edema](https://www.rxlist.com/edema/definition.htm) - Eye irritation - Retinitis (inflammation [Ocular](https://www.rxlist.com/ocular/definition.htm)palsies (eye muscle weakness) - Polyneuritis/polyneuropathy (simultaneous inflammation/damage to multiple nerves all over the body) [Encephalitis](https://www.rxlist.com/encephalitis/definition.htm)(inflammation of the [brain](https://www.rxlist.com/brain/definition.htm)) [Encephalopathy](https://www.rxlist.com/encephalopathy/definition.htm)(damage to the brain) [Acute](https://www.rxlist.com/acute/definition.htm)disseminated [encephalomyelitis](https://www.rxlist.com/encephalomyelitis/definition.htm)(ADEM), inflammation of the and [spinal cord](https://www.rxlist.com/spinal_cord/definition.htm) - Measles inclusion body encephalitis [Aseptic](https://www.rxlist.com/aseptic/definition.htm) around the brain spinal [cord](https://www.rxlist.com/cord/definition.htm)) [Meningoencephalitis](https://www.rxlist.com/meningoencephalitis/definition.htm) [Transverse myelitis](https://www.rxlist.com/transverse_myelitis/definition.htm)(inflammation of spinal cord) [Tremor](https://www.rxlist.com/tremor/definition.htm) - Seizures Febrile seizures (convulsions caused by fever) [Nerve](https://www.rxlist.com/nerve/definition.htm) [deafness](https://www.rxlist.com/deafness/definition.htm) [Ear](https://www.rxlist.com/ear/definition.htm)pain - Agitation - Apathy - Nervousness - Dream abnormality - Hypersomnia ( [excessive daytime sleepiness](https://www.rxlist.com/excessive_daytime_sleepiness/definition.htm)) like a [Angioedema](https://www.rxlist.com/angioedema/definition.htm)(swelling in the tissue under the skin edema [Peripheral](https://www.rxlist.com/peripheral/definition.htm)edema medical symptoms and a painful rash) - Henoch-Schönlein [purpura](https://www.rxlist.com/purpura/definition.htm)(a condition that causes generalized Lymphadenitis ( [lymph [sweating](https://www.rxlist.com/sweating/definition.htm) [Arthritis](https://www.rxlist.com/arthritis/definition.htm)(joint inflammation) [Arthropathy](https://www.rxlist.com/arthropathy/definition.htm)(joint [anemia](https://www.rxlist.com/anemia/definition.htm)due to inadequate [red blood cell](https://www.rxlist.com/red_blood_cell/definition.htm)production) - Extravasation (leakage of fluid out of blood vessels) [Hematuria](https://www.rxlist.com/hematuria/definition.htm)(blood in [urine](https://www.rxlist.com/urine/definition.htm)) - With rotavirus [vaccination](https://www.rxlist.com/vaccination/definition.htm): - Gastroenteritis with vaccine viral in infants with [severe combined immunodeficiency disease](https://www.rxlist.com/severe_combined_immunodeficiency_disease/definition.htm)( [SCID](https://www.rxlist.com/scid/definition.htm)) [Intussusception](https://www.rxlist.com/intussusception/definition.htm), a condition in which part of the [intestine](https://www.rxlist.com/intestine/definition.htm)slides into the [adjacent](https://www.rxlist.com/adjacent/definition.htm)part [Kawasaki disease](https://www.rxlist.com/kawasaki_disease/definition.htm), a condition that causes inflammation in the walls of blood vessels - Gastroenteritis with vaccine viral shedding in infants with - Severe dengue infection (with dengue vaccine) Information contained herein is not intended to cover all possible side effects, precautions, warnings, drug interactions, allergic reactions, or adverse effects. Check with your [doctor](https://www.rxlist.com/doctor/definition.htm) or [pharmacist](https://www.rxlist.com/pharmacist/definition.htm) to make sure these drugs do not cause any harm when you take them along with other medicines. Never stop taking your [medication](https://www.rxlist.com/medication/definition.htm) and never change your dose or frequency without consulting your doctor. What are names of live viral vaccines? [Generic](https://www.rxlist.com/generic/definition.htm) and brand names of live viral vaccines include: [ACAM2000](https://www.rxlist.com/acam2000-drug.htm) - adenovirus types 4 and 7 live, oral - dengue vaccine [Dengvaxia](https://www.rxlist.com/dengvaxia-drug.htm) - Ebola Zaire vaccine [Ervebo](https://www.rxlist.com/ervebo-drug.htm) [FluMist](https://www.rxlist.com/flumist-drug.htm)Quadrivalent - vaccine, [vaccinia](https://www.rxlist.com/vaccinia/definition.htm)) and monkeypox vaccine, live, nonreplicating - smallpox (vaccinia) vaccine, live - varicella virus vaccine live [Varivax](https://www.rxlist.com/varivax-drug.htm) - yellow fever vaccine - YF Vax [Zostavax](https://www.rxlist.com/zostavax-drug.htm)(DSC) - discontinued - zoster vaccine live (discontinued) From Infectious Disease Resources Featured Centers Health Solutions From Our
